That's great to hear about your consistent Sunday evening runs! Increasing your distance to 5 km is a fantastic goal, and with proper preparation, you can minimize the risk of injuries. Here are some tips to help you safely increase your running distance:

1. **Gradual Progression**: Don't try to do too much too soon. Gradually increase your distance by no more than 10% each week. This allows your body to adapt to the demands of running longer distances.
2. **Listen to Your Body**: Pay attention to your body's signals. If you experience any pain or discomfort, stop and rest. It's better to take a day off or modify your workout than to risk injury.
3. **Warm-up and Cool-down**: Always warm up with 10-15 minutes of light cardio (jogging, jumping jacks, etc.) and stretching before your run. After your run, cool down with static stretches to help your body recover.
4. **Proper Footwear**: Wear shoes designed for running, and make sure they fit comfortably. Consider replacing your shoes every 300-400 miles or every 3-4 months.
5. **Running Form**: Focus on proper running form to reduce the impact on your joints. Keep your posture upright, land midfoot or forefoot instead of heel striking, and try to maintain a consistent stride.
6. **Incorporate Strength Training**: Strengthening your core, glutes, and legs can help you maintain good form and reduce the risk of injuries. Focus on exercises like squats, lunges, and leg press.
7. **Hydrate and Fuel**: Proper hydration and nutrition are crucial for optimal performance. Make sure to drink plenty of water before, during, and after your runs, and fuel your body with a balanced diet that includes complex carbohydrates, protein, and healthy fats.
8. **Rest and Recovery**: Allow your body time to recover between runs. Aim for at least one or two rest days per week, and prioritize sleep (7-9 hours) to help your body repair and adapt.
9. **Incorporate Walk Breaks**: If you're new to running longer distances, consider incorporating walk breaks every 10-15 minutes to give your body a chance to recover. This can help you build endurance and reduce the risk of burnout.
10. **Get Professional Guidance**: If you're new to running or have concerns about injuries, consider consulting a running coach or a sports medicine professional for personalized guidance.

Remember, increasing your distance takes time and patience. Be kind to your body, and don't be afraid to take a step back if you need to. Good luck, and I hope you crush your 5 km goal!
